[[File:Exposição_de_etnologia_africana_e_afrobrasileira_do_Museu_Nacional_01.jpg|thumb|General view room with African and Afro-Brazilian objects, in the National Museum. (2015).
]] The '''Kumbukumbu Room''', or '''Kumbukumbu Room: Africa, Memory and Heritage''', or '''Kumbukumbu Exhibition''', was one of the spaces of the [[National Museum of Brazil]], destroyed by the [[National Museum of Brazil fire|fire of 2018]]. The name of the room refers to a word in [[Swahili language|Swahili]], used for "objects, people or events that make us think about the past." In the room, objects from the [[Africa|African]] and [[Afro-Brazilians|Afro-Brazilian]] collections were on display. In particular, the collections [[Police of the Court collection|Police of the Court]] and Heloísa Alberto Torres were featured. Also in the room were the set of gifts from Africa sent to [[John VI of Portugal|John, the Clement]], in 1810, including the Throne of the [[King of Dahomey]]. Most of the objects on display were from the 19th century. The room was organized from nine showcases, six side and three central, and a map from which one could establish the origin of the exposed pieces. According to the official book of presentation of the exhibition: {| class="cquote2" style="text-align: left; border-collapse: collapse; border-style: none; background-color: transparent; margin-bottom: 58px;" | id="24" style="width:20px; vertical-align:top; color:#B2B7F2;font-size:40px;font-family:serif;font-weight:bold;text-align:left;padding:10px 10px;" |“ | id="26" style="padding:4px 10px;" |Walking through the exhibition room clockwise, from the front door, we have the first showcase, [[Africa]], past and present, which gives an overview of the African continent; the second deals with the [[colonial war]]; the third exhibits objects from the equatorial forest peoples and is related to the central showcase, which shows a large [[elephant tusk]]; the fourth presents [[Angola]] after the [[Slavery in Africa|Atlantic slavery]]; and fifth, the gifts sent by the king of Dahomey to the [[king of Portugal]] as part of its diplomacy of friendship.The flag and throne are also part of this group, which are exhibited in the two other central windows. The last showcase is devoted to the [[Africans in Brazil]], covering both Africans born in Africa and their descendants. | id="30" style="width:20px; vertical-align:top; color:#B2B7F2;font-size:40px;font-family:serif;font-weight:bold;text-align:right;padding:10px 10px;" |” |} == Division == The room was divided into six spaces: * The Diplomacy of Friendship * The colonial war  * Africans in Brazil  * Angola after the Atlantic slavery  * The people of the equatorial forest * Africa past and present {{Reflist}} == External link == * [http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/etnologia/kumbukumbu.html Official page]. * [http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/etnologia/LivroKumbukumbu.pdf Book about the exhibition.] [[Category:National Museum of Brazil]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox COA case |Litigants=Lee v. Keith |Court=[[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]] |CourtSeal= |ArgueDate=June 9, |ArgueYear=2006 |DecideDate=September 18, |DecideYear=2006 |FullName=David Lee v. John Keith, et al |Citations=[https://openjurist.org/463/f3d/763 463 F.3d 763] (7th Cir. 2006) |Prior= |Subsequent= |Holding= |Judges=[[Kenneth Francis Ripple]], [[Daniel Anthony Manion]], [[Diane S. Sykes]] |Majority=Sykes |JoinMajority=Ripple, Manion |LawsApplied={{hlist | [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] | [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]]}} }} '''''Lee v. Keith''''', 463 F.3d 763 (7th Cir. 2006){{cite court |litigants=Lee v. Keith |vol=463 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=763 |pinpoint= |court=7th Cir. |date=2006 |url=https://openjurist.org/463/f3d/763 |accessdate=2017-09-18 |quote=}} was a case in which, on September 18, 2006,[http://freeandequal.org/leevkeith.htm Illinois election law ruled unconstitutional: Lee V. Keith, 2006], [[Coalition for Free and Equal Elections]] the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]] struck down Illinois' [[ballot access]] laws, opining:
In combination, the ballot access requirements for independent legislative candidates in Illinois--the early filing deadline, the 10% signature requirement, and the additional statutory restriction that disqualifies anyone who signs an independent candidate's nominating petition from voting in the primary--operate to unconstitutionally burden the freedom of political association guaranteed by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. Ballot access barriers this high--they are the most restrictive in the nation and have effectively eliminated independent legislative candidacies from the Illinois political scene for a quarter of a century--are not sustainable based on the state's asserted interest in deterring party splintering, factionalism, and frivolous candidacies.[http://www.wsws.org/articles/2006/sep2006/illi-s20.shtml Judge orders election board to certify Illinois SEP candidate], Jerome White, Sept. 20, 2006.

page.title: List of films shot at the Palace of Versailles

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=April 2013}} This is a list of the films shot at the [[Palace of Versailles]] including its interior and [[Gardens of Versailles|its palace gardens]]. All films listed here have the approval of the museum administration for [[location shooting]]. Some of the films have an unknown title. The dates given are the dates of shooting. Most films have are shot and released in French. Some are shot and released in English.
==1900s== *''Reconstitution d’une fête sous Louis XIV'' (1904) *''Plusieurs scènes sur Marie-Antoinette'' (1908) Directors: Henri Lavedan et Georges Lenôtre *''Reconstitution historique'' (1908) Director: Georges Fagot *''Vues cinématographiques'' (1909) Director: Georges Fagot
==1910s== *''Vues cinématographiques et reconstitution de scènes'' (1910) Director: Max Lyon *''Reproduction de scènes historiques de l’époque Louis XIV'' (1910) *''L’affaire du collier de la Reine'' (1911) Director: Camille de Morchon *''Vues cinématographiques'' (1) (1911) Director: C. Gilbert *''Vues cinématographiques'' (2) (1911) Director: Jacques Brindejont-Offenbach *''Vues cinématographiques'' (3) (1911) *''Vues cinématographiques'' (1) (1913) *''Vues cinématographiques en couleur'' (2) (1913) *''Vues cinématographiques'' (3) (1913) Director: Arthur Bernede *''Vue cinématographique'' (1915) *''Scènes cinématographiques'' (1916) Director: M. Rivers *''Films d’une pièce historique tirée de la guerre actuelle'' (1917) Director: Th. Drouvillé

page.title: Museo de la Exploración Rudolph Amandus Philippi

revision.text:
'''''Museum of Human Beings''''', included in the National American Indian Heritage Month Booklist, November 2012 and 2013<ref>[http://www.npl.lib.va.us/bibliographies/2012aihm.pdf// American Heritage Booklist November 2012].</ref> is a novel written by [[Colin Sargent]], which delves into the heart-rending life of Jean-Baptiste Charbonneau, the son of Sacagawea.<ref>[http://eventful.com/washington/events/views-field-alan-cheuse-and-colin-sargent-lectur-/E0-001-018248392-2// Eventful.com via Smithsonian Institution]</ref> [[Sacagawea]] was the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] guide, who at 16 led the [[Lewis and Clark]] expedition.
==Summary== At the turn of the nineteenth century, the young Indian woman Sacagawea leads Lewis and Clark to the Pacific. But what about that tiny infant in the commemorative engraving, perched on Sacagawea’s back? He is her son, Jean-Baptiste Charbonneau, the youngest member of the Expedition, a child caught between two worlds who grows into a man haunted by the mother he barely knew and the wilderness she betrayed. Sacagawea is only sixteen when she leads the Expedition and catches the eye of William Clark who finds her exotically appealing. Afterwards, Clark takes in Sacagawea and her child, and raises Baptiste as a foster son. When the teenage Baptiste attracts the notice of the visiting Duke Paul, Prince of Wurttemberg, Clark approves of the duke’s “experiment” to educate the boy at court. A gleeful Duke Paul exhibits Baptiste throughout Europe as a “half gentleman-half animal.” Eventually Jean Baptiste turns his back on the Old World and returns to the New, determined to find his true place there. He travels deep into the heart of the American wilderness, and into the depths of his mother’s soul, on an epic quest for identity that brings sacrifice, loss, and the distant promise of redemption.
==Reviews==
The expedition [[papoose]] Charbonneau appears on the front of the [[Sacagawea dollar|Sacagawea gold one-dollar coin]] (2000 to 2008) and remains in circulation in the United States today.<ref>[http://coins.about.com/od/famousrarecoinprofiles/p/sacagawea_coin.html// Famous Rare Coin Profiles: Gold Dollar].</ref>
Calling the story “heart-wrenching,” [[Smithsonian Institution]]<ref>[http://smithsonian.com/ Smithsonian Institution].</ref> has recognized the work of fiction with a publication reading at the Smithsonian’s [[National Museum of the American Indian]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]
Described by publisher [[McBooks Press]]<ref>[http://www.mcbooks.com// McBooks Press].</ref> of [[Ithaca]], [[New York (state)|New York]], as “haunting,” the novel tracks the young man’s descent into deepest, darkest civilization in a search for his place in the world: At the turn of the nineteenth century, the young Indian woman Sacagawea leads Lewis and Clark to the [[Pacific Ocean]]. But what about that tiny infant in the commemorative engraving, perched on Sacagawea’s back? He is her son, Jean-Baptiste Charbonneau, the youngest member of the Expedition, a child caught between two worlds who grows into a man haunted by the mother he barely knew and the wilderness she betrayed.
{{quote|“Sacagawea is only sixteen when she leads the Expedition and catches the eye of William Clark who finds her exotically appealing. Afterwards, Clark takes in Sacagawea and her child, and raises Baptiste as a foster son. When the teenage Baptiste attracts the notice of the visiting Duke Paul, Prince of Wurttemberg, Clark approves of the duke’s ‘experiment’ to educate the boy at court. A gleeful Duke Paul exhibits Baptiste throughout Europe as a ‘half gentleman-half animal.’ Eventually Jean Baptiste turns his back on the Old World and returns to the New, determined to find his true place there. He travels deep into the heart of the American wilderness, and into the depths of his mother’s soul, on an epic quest for identity that brings sacrifice, loss, and the distant promise of redemption.”<ref>[http://www.museumofhumanbeings.com/mohb/?page_id=107// From the Author of ''Museum of Human Beings''].</ref> }}
Duke Paul of Wurttemberg’s journal ''Erste Reise nach dem nordlichen Amerika in den Jahren 1822-1824'', translated by W. Robert Nitske and edited by [[Savoie Lottinville]] as ''Travels in North America, 1822-1824'', includes individual entries documenting the botanist nobleman's taking the precocious young Charbonneau, whom Clark had adopted and educated in [[St Louis]], to Germany with him with the promise of further education, departing [[New Orleans]] aboard the brig ''[[Smyrna (ship)|Smyrna]]'' in January 1824. Adept at languages including [[Mandan language|Mandan]], French, [[Latin language|Latin]], English, [[German language|German]], and Spanish, the young Charbonneau spent over five years at court. In the novel, young Baptiste travels across the Levant with Duke Paul and the prince’s painting companion Vogelweide, and performs piano in the presence of Beethoven.
According to ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'':<ref>[http://publishersweekly.com/ Publishers Weekly].</ref>
{{quote|“''Playwright Sargent’s debut novel is a stylish look at the fate of Sacagawea’s baby son, Jean Baptiste Charbonneau, the first Native American to tour Europe—as a curiosity and entertainment, of course. Twenty-four-year-old Sacagawea, though married, becomes William Clark’s lover while helping guide the Lewis and Clark Expedition; after she dies on the trail, Clark adopts her son, Baptiste. Soon, Clark establishes his home in [[St. Louis]], as well as a garish [[museum]] dedicated to his expedition, and sets to educating his new son. Soon, Baptiste is traveling [[Europe]] under the protection of Duke Paul, a cruel man who, when he isn’t exhibiting the boy to royal courts, repeatedly rapes young Baptiste. Six years later, Baptiste returns to [[United States|America]] (astonishingly, still accompanied by Paul), where he confronts Clark over his mother’s mysterious death; unsatisfied and restless, Baptiste heads west and finds work as a fur trapper, an Army scout and gold prospector. Increasingly haunted by his mother, Baptiste revisits her in memories and visions that lend themselves nicely to Sargent’s lyrical prose. With historical cameos (Beethoven, Kit Carson, Washington Irving) and an impressively rounded portrait of the laid-back, introspective, nomadic Baptiste, this novel will satisfy fans of American history.''<ref>[http://www.museumofhumanbeings.com/mohb/?page_id=18// Publisher Weekly on ''Museum of Human Beings''].</ref>}}
==Notes== The ''Museum of Human Beings'' in the title alludes to the notorious [[museum]] that General [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]] built beside his home in [[St Louis]] after he returned from the Lewis and Clark Expedition. Inside, Clark kept relics and specimens related to his various [[indigenous people of the Americas|American Indian]] affairs.
==Further reading== *Sargent, Colin (2008). ''Museum of Human Beings''. Ithaca: [[McBooks]].<ref>[http://mcbooks.com/ McBooks], Ithaca, USA.</ref> *''Publishers Weekly'', Sara Nelson, ed. September 1, 2008. New York: [[Reed Business]]. *Paul, Duke of Wurttemberg (1824). ''Erste Reise nach dem nordlichen Amerika in den Jahren 1822-1824'', W. Robert Nitske, trans., Savoie Lottinville, ed., as ''Travels in North America, 1822–1824''. Norman: [[University of Oklahoma Press]].
==References== <references /> *[http://www.bookbrowse.com/reader_reviews/index.cfm/book_number/2237/museum-of-human-beings A Wonderful Work of Fiction--Rooted in America’s Legendary Past] by [[John Michael Cummings]], author of "[https://web.archive.org/web/20121105133812/http://www.johnmichaelcummings.com/ The Night I Freed John Brown]" *[http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-59013-167-1 With historical cameos (Beethoven, Kit Carson, Washington Irving) and an impressively rounded portrait of the laid-back, introspective, nomadic Baptiste, this novel will satisfy fans of American history] (Nov.) by [[Publishers Weekly]]. 1 September 2008. *[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/museum-of-human-beings-colin-sargent/1100393321 Spooky like Hawthorne, with a Toni Morrison-like sense of place. It's a huge and important project.] by [[Joan Connor]], AWP Award winner, for ''History Lessons'' *[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/museum-of-human-beings-colin-sargent/1100393321 Magic. There is real heart . . . real depth and humanity . . . full of polish and authority . . . I stand to applaud [Sargent's<nowiki>]</nowiki> talent. He's the real thing.] by [[Jack Driscoll]], author of "[[Jack Driscoll|How Like an Angel]]" *[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/museum-of-human-beings-colin-sargent/1100393321 A grand and interesting romp through history, an intriguing, masterfully written novel.] by [http://www.michaelcwhite.com/ Michael C. White], author of ''Soul Catcher'' *[http://www.portlandmonthly.com/portmag/about/news-about-us/ In pulsating prose that triggers all of the senses, Museum of Human Beings takes us on a spirited journey to discover the far-flung life of Sacagawea’s son. Smart, imaginative, and historically-informed, this novel contains heartbreaks of many dimensions, all of them believable and thought-provoking. It captivated me, start to finish.] by [[Bunny McBride]], Pulitzer nominee and author of "[[Bunny McBride|Women of the Dawn]]" and "[[Bunny McBride|Molly Spotted Elk: A Penobscot in Paris]]" *[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/museum-of-human-beings-colin-sargent/1100393321 One of the most satisfying works of fiction that I have read in years . . . Sargent sends the youthful Baptiste on a multi-leveled grand tour of discovery that never lets up or disappoints.] by [[Maine Sunday Telegram]] / [[Portland Press Herald]]. *[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/museum-of-human-beings-colin-sargent/1100393321 This memorable novel will captivate all who read it. Highly recommended for all public library historical fiction collections.] by Melody Ballard of [[Library Journal]]. *[http://www.npl.lib.va.us/bibliographies/2012aihm.pdf "Heart-wrenching"] by [[Smithsonian Institution]] *[http://www.pw.org/content/colin_sargent "This debut novel...belongs with the best of historical fiction"] by [[Foreword Reviews|Foreword Magazine]]
==External links== *[http://museumofhumanbeings.com/ ''Museum of Human Beings'' website] *[http://www.colinsargent.com/ Colin Sargent website] *[http://denverpost.com/books/ci_11091383 Article], ''[[Denver Post]]'' *[http://jeanbaptistecharbonneau.com/ Biography of Jean Baptiste Charbonneau] *[http://lewisandclarkjournals.unl.edu/ Journals of Lewis and Clark Expedition] *[http://www.lewisandclarktrail.com/sacajawea.htm Lewis and Clark guided by Sacagawea] *[http://www.goldeneaglecoin.com/Dollars/Sacagawea_Dollars?gclid=CMKM9KDaybMCFexFMgodM1MAjQ Sacagawea gold one-dollar coin]

[[File:Perchtenmaske.jpg|thumb|right|150px|A ''perchten'' mask from [[Salzburg]] in Austria.]] '''''Perchtenlaufen''''' is a folk custom found in the [[Euroregion Tyrol – South Tyrol – Trentino|Tyrol]] region of central Europe. Occurring on set occasions, the ceremony involves two groups of locals fighting against one another using wooden canes and sticks. Both groups are masked, one as 'beautiful' and the other as 'ugly' Perchte.<ref>[[#Gin83|Ginzburg 1983]]. p. 57.</ref>
==Activity== In the state of [[Styria]], Southeastern Austria, all of the ''Perchtln'' were played by women right into the 19th century. As a part of this, they blackened their faces, wore their hair long and sometimes exposed their breasts.<ref name="Duerr 1985 33">[[#Du85|Duerr 1985]]. p. 33.</ref> In the mid-20th century, one old woman was recorded as saying that when she was young she remembered seeing a female ''Perchtln'' from the Styrian municipality of [[Donnersbach]] who carried a swaddled baby. She related that many of the women dressed as ''Perchtln'' would let one breast hang out, but that they were so well disguised that "no one needed to be ashamed."<ref name="Duerr 1985 33"/>
In January 1977, the German anthropologist [[Hans Peter Duerr]] attended the ''Perchtenlaufen'' in Styria, noting that by that time there were no more female ''Perchtln'', with youths instead having taken up all of those roles.<ref name="Duerr 1985 226">[[#Du85|Duerr 1985]]. p. 226.</ref>
==Interpretations== The Italian historian [[Carlo Ginzburg]] made reference to the ''perchtenlaufen'' in his book ''[[The Night Battles|The Night Battles: Witchcraft and Agrarian Cults in the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries]]'' (1966, English translation 1983). He noted similarities between the ''perchtenlaufen'' and the ''[[benandanti]]'', a visionary tradition which existed in Early Modern [[Friuli]], a province in Northeastern Italy, which was the primary focus of ''The Night Battles''. He remarked that the ''perchtenlaufen'' was "undoubtedly a remnant of the ancient ritual battles" which he believed had originally been based around the fertility of the crops.<ref>[[#Gin83|Ginzburg 1983]]. pp. 57–58.</ref>
Ginzburg's comparison between the ''perchtenlaufen'' and the ''benandanti'' was adopted by the German anthropologist [[Hans Peter Duerr]] in his book ''[[Dreamtime (Duerr book)|Dreamtime: Concerning the Boundary between Wilderness and Civilization]]'' (1978, English translation 1985). He also compared it to the case of the [[Thiess of Kaltenbrun|Livonian werewolf]], arguing that they all represent a clash between the forces of order and chaos.<ref name="Duerr 1985 32-39">[[#Due85|Duerr 1985]]. pp. 32–39.</ref>
==References== ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
===Bibliography=== ;Academic sources {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |title=Dreamtime: Concerning the Boundary between Wilderness and Civilization |last=Duerr |first=Hans Peter |authorlink=Hans Peter Duerr |others=Felicitas Goodman (translator) |year=1985 |origyear=1978 |publisher=Blackwell |location=Oxford and New York |isbn= 0-631-13375-5 |ref=Due85}} * {{cite book |title= The Night Battles: Witchcraft and Agrarian Cults in the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries |last=Ginzburg |first=Carlo |authorlink=Carlo Ginzburg |others=John and Anne Tedeschi (translators) |year= 1983 |origyear=1966 |publisher= Johns Hopkins Press |location= Baltimore |isbn=0-8018-4386-3 |ref=Gin83}} {{refend}}
==External links==
* [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/picturegalleries/worldnews/11263371/Scary-monsters-scare-away-evil-spirits-in-Perchten-pagan-festival-in-Germany.html Scary monsters scare away evil spirits in Perchten pagan festival in Germany] — photo gallery published by [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] featuring work by Philipp Guelland

{{Infobox book | name = Plantae Asiaticae Rariores | title_orig = | translator = | image = Nathaniel Wallich - Plantae Asiaticae Rariores - vol. I title 1 (1830).jpg | caption = The title page of the 1830 edition
of ''Plantae Asiaticae Rariores'' | author = [[Nathaniel Wallich]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] | language = English | series = | subject = [[Botany]] | genre = {{Unbulleted list | [[Science]] | [[Biology]]}} | publisher = Richard Taylor for ''Treuttel and Würtz'' | release_date = 1830–1832 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]]) | pages = | isbn = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Plantae Asiaticae Rariores''''' is a horticultural work (alternative title ''Descriptions and figures of a select number of unpublished East Indian plants'') published in 1830–1832 by the [[Denmark|Danish]] [[botanist]] [[Nathaniel Wallich]]. ''Plantae Asiaticae Rariores'' was published in London, Paris and Strassburg between 1829 and 1832 and consisted of 3 volumes bound from the 12 original parts in folio size (21½ × 14½ inches) with 294 hand-coloured plates lithographed by [[Maxim Gauci]]. Wallich went on extended leave in 1828 to supervise the printing and hand-colouring of the illustrations in England. Foremost of the watercolour artists who executed the original paintings were two Indian artists, Vishnupersaud, responsible for 114 plates and Gorachand for 87. Vishnupersaud (occasionally referred to as Vishnu Prasad) was an Indian artist frequently employed by naturalists working in India, such as [[John Forbes Royle]] and [[Francis Buchanan-Hamilton]]. Vishnupersaud’s skill was legendary and [[Wilfrid Jasper Walter Blunt|Wilfrid Blunt]] included one of his watercolours in his book ''The Art of Botanical Illustration'' as displaying great craftsmanship. The remaining plates were done by Charles M. Curtis (7), [[William Griffith (botanist)|William Griffith]] (3), [[Sarah Drake]], and various others. A double-page engraved map of India created by [[John Arrowsmith (cartographer)|John Arrowsmith]], showed the routes followed by various botanists.[http://www.georgeglazer.com/prints/nathist/botanical/wallichinv/wallichinv.html George Glazer Gallery] A noteworthy point is that plate number 6 is an engraving by H. Weddell, and not a lithograph. ''Plantae Asiaticae'' was seen to follow naturally on [[William Roxburgh]]'s ''Plants of the coast of Coromandel'' (London: 1795–1820) and was sponsored by the [[East India Company]] who subscribed to 40 copies. The 12 parts were sold at £2 10s each, between September 1829 and August 1832. Wallich writes in the introduction, "The present Work consists of a selection of plants made chiefly from a series of 1200 drawings, executed under my direction by Native Artists." He goes on to praise the work of the lithographer Maxim Gauci and the colourist John Clark: "For both of these worthy men and admirable artists I beg to express my sincere respect." [http://www.donaldheald.com/search/search_01.php?Author=WALLICH%2C%20Nathaniel Donald A Heald] == Gallery of plates == Image:Plantae Plate293.jpg|''Jackiopsis ornata'' Image:Nathaniel Wallich00.jpg|''Saurauia nepalensis'' Image:Nathaniel Wallich01.jpg|''Osbeckia angustifolia'' Image:Nathaniel Wallich02.jpg|''Osbeckia ternifolia'' Image:Nathaniel Wallich03.jpg|''Dillenia aurea'' Image:Curcuma parviflora Wallich vol1 57.jpg|''Curcuma parviflora'' Image:Epipremnum pinnatum.jpg|''Epipremnum pinnatum'' Image:Kaempferia candida Wallich vol1 56.jpg|''Kaempferia candida'' Image:Kaempferia elegans Wallich vol1 27.jpg|''[[Kaempferia elegans]]'' Image:Maranta ramosissima Wallich_vol3 286.jpg|''Maranta ramosissima'' Image:Roscoea capitata Wallich_vol3 255.jpg|''Roscoea_capitata'' Image:Roscoea purpurata purpurata_R. procera Wallich vol3 242.jpg|''Roscoea purpurata purpurata'' Image:Zingiber barbatum Wallich vol1 55.jpg|''Zingiber barbatum'' == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|Plantae Asiaticae Rariores}} *[http://www.botanicus.org/title/b12006506 Botanicus Digital Library at Missouri Botanical Garden] [[Category:Florae (publication)]] [[Category:Botany books]] [[Category:Botany in Asia]]

revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=July 2016}} [[File:Public opinion of interracial marriage in the United States.png|thumb|526x526px|Graph indicating the extent to which US citizens agree or disagree with [[interracial marriage]], spanning 1958-2007.]] '''Sexual racial preference''' is the individual's sexual preference of specific races. It is an inclination towards potential sexual or romantic partners on the basis of perceived racial identity. Not everyone agrees that this should be classified as racism, some argue that distinguishing among partners on the basis of perceived race is not racism at all but a justifiable personal preference.<ref>Callander, D., Newman, C. E., & Holt, M. (2015). Is sexual racism really racism? Distinguishing attitudes toward sexual racism and generic racism among gay and bisexual men. Archives of sexual behavior, 44(7), 1991-2000.</ref> The origins of sexual racism can be explained by looking at its history, especially in the US, where the abolition of slavery and the [[Reconstruction Era]] had significant impacts on interracial mixing. Attitudes towards interracial relationships, and indeed marriage, have increased in positivity in the last 50 years. In 1968, 73% of US citizens disapproved of the right to marry inter-racially, whereas this figure dropped to 17% by 2007, this illustrating the reduction in discriminatory attitudes towards interracial dating.<ref>Carroll, J. (2007, August 16). Most Americans approve of interracial marriages. Retrieved from http:// www.gallup.com/poll/28417/most-americansapprove-interracial-marriages.aspx</ref> Irrespective of this, there still remains the issue of sexual racism in the [[Online dating service|online dating]] world, in that preferences appear to follow a racial hierarchy.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} Sharing the basic premise, originating from the '[[taboo]]' nature of interracial relations, individuals of other racial groups are classified as forbidden sexual objects; the result of a [[Racial fetishism|racial fetish]].
== History ==
=== United States of America ===
After the abolition of [[slavery]] in 1865, the white Americans showed an increasing fear of racial mixture.<ref>Yancey, G. (2007). "Experiencing Racism: Differences in the Experiences of Whites Married to Blacks and Non-Black Racial Minorities". Journal of Comparative Family Studies. University of Calgary: Social Sciences. 38 (2): 197–213.</ref> The remnants of the racial divide became stronger post-slavery as the concept of [[Whiteness studies|whiteness]] developed. There was a widely held belief that uncontrollable lust threatens the purity of the nation. This increased white anxiety about interracial sex, and has been described through [[Montesquieu]]'s climatic theory in his book the [[The Spirit of the Laws|Spirit of the Laws]], which explains how people from different climates have different temperaments, "The inhabitants of warm countries are, like old men, timorous; the people in cold countries are, like young men, brave."<ref>De Montesquieu, C. (1989). Montesquieu: The Spirit of the Laws. Cambridge University Press.</ref> At the time, black women held the jezebel stereotype, which claimed black women often initiated sex outside of marriage and were generally sexually promiscuous.<ref>West, C. M. (1995). Mammy, Sapphire, and Jezebel: Historical images of Black women and their implications for psychotherapy. Psychotherapy: Theory, Research, Practice, Training, 32(3), 458.</ref> This idea stemmed from the first encounters between European men and African women. As the men were not used to the extremely hot climate they misinterpreted the women's lack of clothing for vulgarity.<ref>White, D. B. (1999). Ar'n't I a Woman. W.W. Norton & Company.</ref> Similarly, black men were stereotyped for having a specific lust for white women. This created tension, as if white men were having sex with black women because they were more lustful, this meant black men would lust after white women in the same way, this threatened the white male dominance that was apparent at the time, increasing the fear of interracial interactions.
There are a few potential reasons as to why such strong ideas on interracial sex developed. The [[Reconstruction Era]] following the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] started to disassemble traditional aspects of Southern society. The Southerners who were used to being dominant were now no longer legally allowed to run their farms using slavery.<ref>Foner, E. and Mahoney O. (2003). America's Reconstruction: People and Politics After the Civil War.</ref> Many whites struggled with this reformation and attempted to find loopholes to continue the exploitation of black labour. Additionally, the white Democrats were not pleased with the outcome and felt a sense of inadequacy among white men. This led to them taking out their frustration on the black population. This radical reconstruction of the South was deeply unpopular and slowly unravelled leading to the introduction of the [[Jim Crow laws]].<ref>Kousser, J. M. (2003). Jim Crow Laws. Dictionary of American History, 4, 479-480.</ref> There was an increased the sense of white dominance and sexual racism among the Southern people.
There were general heightened tensions following the end of the failed civil war in 1865, and this increased the sexual anxiety in the population. Races did not want to mix, the whites were feeling inadequate and wanted to take back control. The [[Ku Klux Klan]] then formed in 1867, which led to violence and terrorism targeting the black population.<ref>Wade, W. C. (1998). The Fiery Cross: The Ku Klux Klan in America. Oxford University Press, USA.</ref> There was a rise in [[Lynching|lynch]] mob violence where many black men were accused of rape. This was not just senseless violence, but an attempt to preserve 'whiteness' and prevent racial blur, the whites wanted to remain dominant and make sure there was no interracial sexual activity. For example, mixed race couples that chose to live together were sought out and lynched by the KKK. The famous case of Emmett Till who was lynched at the age of fourteen for supposedly whistling at a white women shows the prominence of white male anxiety in the 1950s.<ref>Whitfield, S. J. (1991). A death in the delta: The story of Emmett Till. JHU Press.</ref> When the Jim Crow laws were eventually overturned, it took years for the court to resolve the numerous acts of discrimination.
==Heterosexual community== Sexual racism exists in both the heterosexual and homosexual communities across the globe. The prevalence of interracial couples demonstrate how attitudes have changed in the last 50 years.<ref>Mendelsohn, G. A., Taylor, L. S., Fiore, A. T. & Cheshire, C. (2014). Black/White Dating Online: Interracial Courtship in the 21st Century. Psychology of Popular Media Culture, 3, 2-18.</ref> A case that has perhaps received heightened publicity is that of [[Loving v. Virginia|Mildred and Richard Loving]]. The couple lived in Virginia yet had to marry outside the state due to the [[Anti-miscegenation laws in the United States|anti-miscegenation]] laws present in nearly half of the US states in 1958. Once married, the pair returned to Virginia, and were both arrested in their home for the infringement of the [[Racial Integrity Act of 1924|Racial Integrity Act]], and each sentenced to a year in prison. Prior to the repeal of these laws in 2000, several attempts were made to void the sentence, ultimately the couple resorted to relocation to avoid further prejudice.<ref>Moran, R. F. (2007). Loving and the Legacy of Unintended Consequences. Wis. L. Rev, 239, 240-281.</ref> [[File:Bill de Blasio family 2012.jpg|thumb|204x204px|[[Bill de Blasio]] and [[Chirlane McCray]] with their two children in 2012, attending a silent march.]] Around a similar time was the controversy surrounding [[Seretse Khama|Seretse and Ruth Khama]]. Seretse was the chief of an eminent Botswanan tribe, and Ruth an English student. The pair married in 1948 but experienced frequent discrimination from the onset of the relationship, including Seretse's removal from his tribal responsibilities as chief. For nearly 10 years, Seretse and Ruth lived as exiles in Britain, as the racism towards their relationship remained strong. British officials hoped that their asylum in the country would reduce their desire to continue the marriage. Once the couple were allowed to return home in 1956, they became prominent figures the movement for racial and social justice, contributing to Seretse's election as president of Botswana in 1966. Later, they both continued to fight laws surrounding interracial marriage.<ref>Parsons, N. (1993). The impact of Seretse Khama on British public opinion 1948-56 and 1978. Historical Studies in Ethnicity, Migration and Diaspora, 12, 195-219.</ref>
More recent examples portray the increasingly accepting attitudes of the majority to interracial relationships and marriage. In 2013, [[Bill de Blasio]] was elected as Mayor of New York City, accompanied by his wife, [[Chirlane McCray]]. The pair are one of the first interracial couples to stand in power side by side. Both de Blasio and McCray are active political figures, and although they are not exempt from racial discrimination, the attitudes of the world to interracial marriage are much more positive and optimistic than in previous decades.<ref>Werner, D. & Mahler, H. (2014). Primary health care: The Return of Health for All. World Nutrition, 5(4), 336-365.</ref> Across much of the world, it is ever increasingly the situation that interracial couples can live, marry and have children without prosecution that was previously rife, due to major changes in law along with reductions in discriminatory attitudes. Sexual racism also exists in the [[Heterosexuality|heterosexual]] community in [[Online dating service|online dating]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kernelmag.dailydot.com/issue-sections/features-issue-sections/11404/online-dating-tinder-racism/|title=The Weird Racial Politics of Online Dating|last=Sankin|first=Aaron|date=January 18, 2015|work=[[The Kernel]]|publisher=The Daily Dot|accessdate=April 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/09/09/no-blacks-is-not-a-sexual-preference-it-s-racism.html|title='No Blacks' Is Not a Sexual Preference. It's Racism|last=Allen|first=Samantha|date=September 9, 2015|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|accessdate=April 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/sexual-racism-the-daily-show_us_5710aa9ce4b0060ccda2e97d|title=Online Dating Is Rife With Sexual Racism, 'The Daily Show' Discovers|last=Mosbergen|first=Dominique|date=April 15, 2016|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=April 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailylife.com.au/life-and-love/love-sex-and-relationships/why-race-is-not-a-sexual-preference-20150914-gjmj2w.html|title=Why Race is Not a Sexual Preference|last=Tuyau|first=Maxine|date=September 15, 2015|work=Daily Life|publisher=Fairfax Media|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915173521/http://www.dailylife.com.au/life-and-love/love-sex-and-relationships/why-race-is-not-a-sexual-preference-20150914-gjmj2w.html|archive-date=September 15, 2015|access-date=September 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2016/04/13/new_daily_show_segment_sexual_racism_is_real.html|title=''The Daily Show''{{'s}} Jessica Williams and Ronny Chieng Team Up to Prove That Yes, Sexual Racism Is Real|last=Bradley|first=Laura|date=April 13, 2016|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|access-date=September 16, 2016}}</ref>
=== Online dating === [[File:OnLineDating World 201602.png|thumb|373x373px|Monthly visitors to different [[Online dating service|Online Dating services]] globally in February 2016]] In the last 15 years, online dating has overtaken previously preferred methods of meeting with potential partners, surpassing both the occupational setting and area of residence as chosen locations. This spike is consistent with an increase in access to the internet in homes across the globe, in addition to the number of dating sites available to individuals differing in [[ageing|age]], [[gender]], [[race (human categorization)|race]], [[sexual orientation]] and [[Ethnic group|ethnic background]].<ref>Rosenfeld, M. J. & Thomas, R. J. (2012). Searching for a Mate: The Rise of the Internet as a Social Intermediary. American Sociological Review, 77(4), 523-547.</ref> Along with this, there has been a rise in online sexual racism, whereby partner race is now the most highly selected preference chosen by users when creating their online profiles, displacing both educational and religious characteristics.<ref name="Hitsch2006">Hitsch, G. J., Hortacsu, A. & Ariely, D. (2006). What makes you click? Partner preferences and matching outcomes in online dating. MIT Sloan Research Paper No. 4603-06.</ref> Research has indicated a progressive acceptance of interracial relationships by White individuals.<ref>Schuman, H., Steeh, C., Bobo, L & Krysan, M. (1997). Racial Attitudes in America: Trends and Interpretations (revised edition): Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.</ref> The majority of White Americans are not against interracial relationships and marriage,<ref>Ludwig, J. (2004). Acceptance of interracial marriage at record high. Retrieved from http://www.gallup.com/poll/11836/acceptance-interracial-marriage-record-high.aspx, 23.11.2016, 20:00pm.</ref> however these [[belief]]s are not illustrated in subsequent marital rates between interracial couples, such that no more than 4% of White Americans will wed outside their own race.<ref>Qian, Z., & Lichter, D. L. (2007). Social boundaries and marital assimilation: Interpreting trends in racial and ethnic intermarriage. American Sociological Review, 72, 68-94.</ref> In fact, less than 46% of White Americans are willing to date an individual of any other race.<ref name="Yancey20092">Yancey, G. (2009). Cross-racial differences in the racial preferences of potential dating partners: A test of the alienation of African Americans and Social Dominance Orientation. The Sociology Quarterly, 50, 121-143.</ref> Overall, African Americans appear to be the most open to interracial relationships,<ref name="Robnett20112">Robnett, B., & Feliciano, C. (2011). Patterns of racial-ethnic exclusion by internet daters. Social Forces, 89, 807-828.</ref> yet are the least preferred partner by other racial groups.<ref name="Yancey20092"/> However, regardless of stated preferences, [[Discrimination|racial discrimination]] still occurs in online dating.<ref name="Hitsch2006" />
Each group significantly prefers to date intra-racially. [[White Americans]] are the least open to interracial dating, and select preferences in the order of [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic Americans]], [[Asian Americans]] and then [[African Americans|African American]] individuals last at 60.5%, 58.5% and 49.4% respectively.<ref name="Robnett20112"/> African American preferences follow a similar pattern, with the most preferred partner belonging to the Hispanic group (61%), followed by White individuals (59.6%) and then Asian Americans (43.5%). Both Hispanic and Asian Americans prefer to date a White individual (80.3% and 87.3%, respectively), and both are least willing to date African Americans (56.5% and 69.5%).<ref name="Yancey20092"/> In all significant cases, Hispanic Americans are preferred to Asian Americans, and Asian Americans are significantly preferred over African Americans.<ref name="Robnett20112" /> Hispanic Americans are less likely to be excluded in online dating [[partner preferences|partner preferences]] by whites seeking a partner, as Latinos are often viewed as a racial group that is increasingly assimilating more into White American [[culture]].<ref>Yancey, G. (2003). Who Is White? Latinos, Asians, And the New Black/nonblack Divide: Lynne Rienner Pub.</ref>
In addition to general racism in online dating, there is further exclusion differences between certain genders within racial groups, such that women of any race are significantly less likely to date inter-racially than a male of any race.<ref>Fisman, R., Sheena S. I., Emir K. & Itamar S. (2006). "Gender differences in mate selection: Evidence from a speed dating experiment." Quarterly Journal of Economics, 121, 673-697.</ref> Specifically, Asian men and Black women face more obstacles to acceptance online.<ref>Spell, S. A. (2016). Not just black and white: how race/ethnicity and gender intersect in hookup culture. Sociology of Race and Ethnicity, 1-16.</ref> White women are most likely to exclude Asian men, likely due to their amplified [[Effeminacy|effeminate]] portrayal in the media.<ref>Kim, E. (1986). "Asian Americans and American Popular Culture." P. 99-114 in Asian American History Dictionary, edited by R. H. Kim. New York: Greenwood Press.</ref><ref>Espiritu, Y. L. (1997). Asian American women and men: labor, laws and love. Thousand Oaks, Calif.: Sage Publications.</ref><ref>Chen, A. S. (1999). "Lives at the centre of the periphery, lives at the periphery of the centre - Chinese American masculinities and bargaining with hegemony." Gender & Society, 13, 584-607.</ref> This exclusion remains present even when considering high earning Asian individuals with an advanced educational background.<ref name="Robnett20112" /><ref>Barringer, H. R., Takeuchi, D. T. & Xenos, P. (1990). "Education, Occupational Prestige, and Income of Asian Americans." Sociology of Education, 63, 27-43.</ref><ref>Massey, D. S. & Denton, N. A. (1992). "Residential Segregation of Asian-Origin Groups in United-States Metropolitan Areas." Sociology and Social Research, 76, 170-177.</ref> Increased education does however influence choices in the other direction, such that a higher level of schooling is associated with more optimistic feelings towards interracial relationships.<ref>Bobo, L. D. & Massagli, M. P. (2001). "Stereotyping and Urban Inequality." P. 89-162 in Urban Inequality, edited by a M. P. M. Lawrence D. Bobo. New York: Russell Sage.</ref> White men are most likely to exclude Black women, as opposed to women of another race. High levels of previous exposure to a variety of racial groups creates a more accepting attitude.<ref>Potârcă, G & Mills, M. (2015). Racial preferences in online dating across European countries. European Sociological Review, 31(3), 326-341.</ref> Sexual racism in online dating, in addition to the outside world, is also influenced by the partner selectors area of residence. Those residing in more Southern regions, particularly in American states, are less likely to have been in an interracial relationship, and are unlikely to inter-racially date in the future.<ref name="Perry20142">Perry, S. L. (2014). Religious Socialisation and Interracial Dating: The effects of childhood religious salience, practice, and parents' tradition. Journal of Family Issues, 1-25.</ref> Location is also related to the individuals current and previous religious practices; those who engaged in regular religious customs at age 12 are less likely to inter-racially date. Moreover, those from a [[Judaism|Jewish]] background are significantly more likely to enter an interracial relationship than those from a [[Protestantism|Protestant]] background, indicating differences in levels of sexual racism present, which translate into the virtual world of online dating.<ref name="Perry20142" />
Currently, there are websites specifically targeted to different couple matches, such that singles can sign up online and focus on one particular partner quality, such as race, religious beliefs or ethnicity. In addition to this, there are online dating services that target race-specific partner choices, and a selection of pages dedicated to interracial dating that allow users to select partners based on age, gender and particularly race. Online dating services experience controversy in this context as debate is cast over whether statements such as "no Asians" or "not attracted to Asians" in user profiles, are racist or just signify individual preference.<ref>Callander, D., Newman, C. E. & Holt, M. (2015). Is Sexual Racism Really Racism? Distinguishing Attitudes Toward Sexual Racism and Generic Racism Among Gay and Bisexual Men. Archives of Sexual Behaviour, 44(7), 1991-2000.</ref> Ethnic minorities who feel they lack dating prospects as a result of their race, sometimes refer to themselves as ''ethnicels''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/star-columnists/2018/05/01/the-foundational-misogyny-of-incels-overlaps-with-racism.html|title=The foundational misogyny of incels overlaps with racism - The Star|publisher=|accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref>
== Homosexual community == [[Asian people|Asian]] men are often represented in media, both mainstream and [[LGBT]], as being feminized and desexualized.{{sfn|Nguyen|2014}} LGBT Asian men often report sexual [[racism]] from [[white people|white]] LGBT men. The [[homosexual|gay]] [[Asian Canadians|Asian-Canadian]] author [[Richard Fung]] has written that while [[black people|black]] men are portrayed as [[sexualization|hypersexualized]], gay Asian men are portrayed as being undersexed.{{sfn|Gross|Woods|1999|pp=235–253}} Fung also wrote about feminizing depictions of Asian men in [[gay pornography]], which often focuses on gay Asian men's submission to the pleasure of white men. According to Fung, gay Asian men tend to ignore or display displeasure with races such as [[Arabs]], blacks, and other Asians but seemingly give sexual acceptance and approval to gay white men. White gay men are more frequently than other racial groups to state "No Asians" when seeking partners. In [[interracial pornography|interracial]] gay male pornography, Asian men are usually portrayed as submissive "[[Top, bottom and versatile#Bottom|bottoms]]".{{sfn|Nguyen|2004|pp=223–228}}
Asian American women also report similar discrimination in lesbian, gay, bisexual (LGB) communities. According to a study by Sung, Szymanski, and Henrichs-Beck (2015), Asian American participants who identified as lesbian or bisexual often reported invisibility, stereotyping, and fetishism in LGB circles and the larger U.S. culture. This is in addition to the heterosexism and invisibility they felt in Asian American communities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sung|first=Mi Ra|last2=Szymanski|first2=Dawn M.|last3=Henrichs-Beck|first3=Christy|title=Challenges, coping, and benefits of being an Asian American lesbian or bisexual woman.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/sgd0000085|journal=Psychology of Sexual Orientation and Gender Diversity|volume=2|issue=1|pages=52–64|doi=10.1037/sgd0000085}}</ref>
Racial sexism is also prevalent in gay online dating. Phua and Kaufman (2003) noted that men seeking men online were more likely than men seeking women to look at racial traits.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Phua|first=Voon C.|last2=Kaufman|first2=Gayle|title=The Crossroads of Race and Sexuality: Date Selection among Men in Internet "Personal" Ads|url=http://www.ingentaselect.com/rpsv/cgi-bin/cgi?ini=xref&body=linker&reqdoi=10.1177/0192513X03256607|journal=Journal of Family Issues|volume=24|issue=8|pages=981–994|doi=10.1177/0192513x03256607}}</ref> Race is often used to advertise oneself or as a criterion in seeking a partner, according to a study looking at Manhunt profiles. In Callander, Newman, and Holt's (2012) study, White participants self-disclosed their racial identity less often than non-White participants, with the implication that Whiteness was the norm and non-Whites expected to self-disclose their racial identity. They cite one profile description as an example: "I shouldn't have to ask for a picture, or your age, or your ethnicity. Have it available straight away or I'll just pass over your profile."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Callander|first=Denton|last2=Holt|first2=Martin|last3=Newman|first3=Christy E.|date=2012-10-01|title=Just a preference: racialised language in the sex-seeking profiles of gay and bisexual men|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13691058.2012.714799|journal=Culture, Health & Sexuality|volume=14|issue=9|pages=1049–1063|doi=10.1080/13691058.2012.714799|issn=1369-1058|pmid=22943583}}</ref>
In a qualitative study conducted by Paul, Ayala, and Choi (2010) with Asian and Pacific Islanders (API), Latino, and African American men seeking men, participants interviewed endorsed racial preference as a common criteria in online dating partner selection.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paul|first=Jay P.|last2=Ayala|first2=George|last3=Choi|first3=Kyung-Hee|date=2010-11-02|title=Internet Sex Ads for MSM and Partner Selection Criteria: The Potency of Race/Ethnicity Online|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00224490903244575|journal=The Journal of Sex Research|volume=47|issue=6|pages=528–538|doi=10.1080/00224490903244575|issn=0022-4499|pmc=3065858|pmid=21322176}}</ref> This reflects the racist power hierarchies often seen in broader spheres of society where Eurocentric discourses are often the standard, and non-Eurocentric discourses are the exceptions.
In another study by Callander, Newman, and Holts, researchers found that attitudes towards sexual racism was often tolerated, with many participants feeling that racial preference was not racism.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Callander|first=Denton|last2=Newman|first2=Christy E.|last3=Holt|first3=Martin|date=2015-07-07|title=Is Sexual Racism Really Racism? Distinguishing Attitudes Toward Sexual Racism and Generic Racism Among Gay and Bisexual Men|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10508-015-0487-3|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|language=en|volume=44|issue=7|pages=1991–2000|doi=10.1007/s10508-015-0487-3|issn=0004-0002}}</ref> They quoted Watts from the Huffington Post, who argued that sexual attraction and racism are not the same: {{quote|Just because someone isn't sexually attracted to someone of Asian origin does not mean they wouldn't want to work, live next to, or socialize with him or her, or that they believe they are somehow naturally superior to them.|as cited in Callander, Newman, & Holts, 2015, p. 1992}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/laurence-watts/gay-racism_b_1307819.html|title=Gay Men And Women Are Not More Racist|last=Author|first=Laurence Watts|last2=News|first2=Features Writer for Pink|date=2012-02-29|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref> This suggests that people find it possible to view larger systemic racial preference as problematic, while viewing racial preferences in romantic or sexual personal relationships as not problematic. Researchers noted that there is a general hesitation to call racial preference "racist", with many defending racial preference as saving time.<ref name=":0" />
In that same study, researchers found that attitudes towards sexual racism were similar to attitudes about generic racism. That is, patterns of sexual racism seems to follow similar patterns of general racism. For example, they found that higher levels of education was associated with more positive attitudes about multiculturalism and less positive attitudes about racial sexism. They also found that experiences of exclusion online due to race was correlated with more accepting views of multiculturalism and less accepting attitudes about sexual racism, regardless of racial identity. These findings suggest that being more aware of racism in general, due to experience or education, and racism's impact had an effect on racial preference such that it was seen as less desirable.<ref name=":0" />
== Fetishisation == [[File:Asian woman tied in red rope.png|thumb|Asian woman tied in red rope from the [[Folsom Street Fair]] 2007]] As well as race-based sexual rejection, sexual racism also manifests in the form of the hypersexualisation of specific ethnic groups. Freudians theorize that [[sexual fetishism]], people of one race can form sexual fixations towards individuals of a separate generalised racial group. This collective [[Racial stereotype|stereotype]] is established through the perception that an individual's sexual appeal derives entirely from their race, and is therefore subject to the [[prejudice]]s that follow.
Racial fetishism as a culture is often perceived, in this context, as an act or belief motivated by sexual racism. The objectification and reductionist perception of different races, for example, East Asian women, or African American men, relies greatly on their portrayal in forms of media that depict them as sexual objects. An example of such a medium includes [[pornography]]. An instance of this hypersexualisation is commented upon in Artist and Designer Donna Choi's illustrative series targeting the specific fetishisation of Asian women, named, ''Does Your Man Suffer From Yellow Fever?'' (2013).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.donnachoi.com/work/yellow-fever.html|title=Does Your Man Suffer From Yellow Fever? {{!}} Donna Choi|website=www.donnachoi.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-06}}</ref> In said illustration, Choi uses satire to depict a white man's harmful perception of a "[[Asian stereotypes|china doll stereotype]]" towards Asian woman and how she is an object to his desires. Choi's intention comes across through implying the presence of an obvious dehumanisation of Asian women in the eyes of another race. This is a deliberate commentary on the fetishisation rooted within the social issue of sexual racism.{{Third-party inline|date=May 2017}}
The effects of Racial Fetishism as a form of Sexual Racism, is discussed in research conducted by Plummer.<ref>Plummer, M. D. (2008). Sexual racism in gay communities: Negotiating the ethnosexual marketplace.</ref> Plummer used qualitative interviews within given focus groups, and found that specific social locations came up as areas in which sexual racism commonly manifest. These mentioned social locations included pornographic media, gay clubs and bars, [[Casual sex|casual sex encounters]] as well as [[romantic relationship]]s. This high prevalence was recorded within Plummer's research to be consequentially related to the recorded lower self-esteem, internalised sexual racism, and increased psychological distress in participants of colour. People subject to this form of racial discernment are targeted in a manner well put by Hook.<ref>Hook, D. (2005). The racial stereotype, colonial discourse, fetishism, and racism. Psychoanalytic Review, 92(5), 702-734.</ref> Hook's historical overview of [[J.M. Coetzee|J.M. Coetzee's]] novel, largely addressed Coetzee's depictions of racial otherness within South Africa. Additionally, Coetzee goes on to write about how the otherness and social detachment from the colonials was what fabricated present racial stereotypes. Such stereotypes are what is said to encourage the perception of other racial groups as ''fantasmatic objects''; a degrading and generalising view of different racial populations.
== See also == * [[Racism in the United States]] * [[Interracial marriage]] * [[Ethnic pornography]] * [[Sexual objectification]] * [[Gendered racism]] * [[Racial fetishism]]
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
==Bibliography== {{refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} : {{cite book |year=1999 |editor1-last=Gross |editor1-first=Larry P. |editor2-last=Woods |editor2-first=James D. |title=The Columbia Reader on Lesbians and Gay Men in Media, Society, and Politics |series=Between Men—Between Women |location=New York |publisher=Columbia University Press |isbn=978-0-231-10446-3 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Marubbio |first=M. Elise |year=2006 |title=Killing the Indian Maiden: Images of Native American Women in Film |location=Lexington |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |isbn=978-0-8131-2414-8 |ref=harv }} :{{cite book |last=Nguyen |first=Hoang Tan |author-link=Nguyen Tan Hoang |chapter=The Resurrection of Brandon Lee: The Making of a Gay Asian American Porn Star |year=2004 |editor-last=Williams |editor-first=Linda |title=Porn Studies |location=Durham, North Carolina |publisher=Duke University Press |pages=223–270 |isbn=978-0-8223-3300-5 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Nguyen |first=Hoang Tan |author-link=Nguyen Tan Hoang |author-mask={{long dash}} |year=2014 |title=A View from the Bottom: Asian American Masculinity and Sexual Representation |series=Perverse Modernities |location=Durham, North Carolina |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-5684-4 |ref=harv }} {{refend}}
==Further reading== {{refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} : {{cite thesis |last=Kudler |first=Benjamin A. |year=2007 |title=Confronting Race and Racism: Social Identity in African American Gay Men |url=http://scholarworks.smith.edu/theses/1341/ |degree=MSW |location=Northampton, Massachusetts |publisher=Smith College |access-date=September 18, 2016 }} : {{cite journal |last=Lay |first=Kenneth James |year=1993 |title=Sexual Racism: A Legacy of Slavery |url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/3qd7s83r |journal=National Black Law Journal |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=165–183 |access-date=September 18, 2016 }} : {{cite journal |last1=Lilly |first1=J. Robert |last2=Thomson |first2=J. Michael |year=1997 |title=Executing US Soldiers in England, World War II: Command Influence and Sexual Racism |journal=[[The British Journal of Criminology]] |volume=37 |issue=2 |pages=262–288 |jstor=23638647 |doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.bjc.a014158 }} : {{cite thesis |last=Plummer |first=Mary Dianne |year=2007 |title=Sexual Racism in Gay Communities: Negotiating the Ethnosexual Marketplace |degree=PhD |location=Seattle |publisher=University of Washington |hdl=1773/9181 }} : {{cite journal |last=Stevenson |first=Howard C, Jr. |year=1994 |title=The Psychology of Sexual Racism and AIDS: An Ongoing Saga of Distrust and the 'Sexual Other' |journal=[[Journal of Black Studies]] |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=62–80 |doi=10.1177/002193479402500104 |issn= 0021-9347 |jstor=2784414 }} {{refend}}
